AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: The Bitternut hickory is a fairly common member in late-successional hardwood forests in the Big Woods region of southern Minnesota. It prefers deep, nutrient-rich soils and often grows with sugar maple, basswood, red oak, American elm, or green ash. The nuts are too bitter to be eaten even by animals. Seedlings can survive for several years with very little light, but need at least partial sunlight from a canopy gap to survive to the sapling stage or beyond.
Pale gray with smooth, narrow forking ridges, and shallow furrows
Male flowers numerous in slender, pendulous catkins 4-10 cm long. 2-4 female flowers on a short spike borne from the apex of branchlets of the current year. Wind pollinated.

3/4-1 1/2" long round, husk-covered nut. Husk thin, coated with yellow powdery scales. 4 parts that split open from tip to middle. The nut is smooth and heart shaped with a prominent point at tip. Bitter inedible seed.

Alternate, pinnately compound, 5-10" long, composed of 7 (sometimes 5 or 9) leaflets each 3-6" long. Leaflets lance-shaped to narrowly elliptic with pointed tip and toothed margins. Glossy dark yellow-green above, lighter and hairy beneath. Autumn color yellow to rusty yellow. Large platelike scales on the leaf underside near the base.
Bright yellow buds and yellowish nuts with leathery husk that splits into four parts
As wide as tall, commonly narrower

ThemeEntityData.Description: The Bitternut hickory is a fairly common member in late-successional hardwood forests in the Big Woods region of southern Minnesota. It prefers deep, nutrient-rich soils and often grows with sugar maple, basswood, red oak, American elm, or green ash. The nuts are too bitter to be eaten even by animals. Seedlings can survive for several years with very little light, but need at least partial sunlight from a canopy gap to survive to the sapling stage or beyond.
